title: CHARACTERIZATION OF THE BENCHMARK BINARY NLTT 33370,
abstract: We report the confirmation of the binary nature of the nearby, very low-mass system NLTT 33370 with adaptive optics imaging and present resolved near-infrared photometry and integrated light optical and near-infrared spectroscopy to characterize the system. VLT-NaCo and LBTI-LMIRCam images show significant orbital motion between 2013 February and 2013 April. Optical spectra reveal weak, gravity sensitive alkali lines and strong lithium 6708 Angstrom absorption that indicate the system is younger than field age. VLT-SINFONI near-IR spectra also show weak, gravity sensitive features and spectral morphology that is consistent with other young, very low-mass dwarfs. We combine the constraints from all age diagnostics to estimate a system age of ~30-200 Myr. The 1.2-4.7 micron spectral energy distribution of the components point toward T_eff=3200 +/- 500 K and T_eff=3100 +/- 500 K for NLTT 33370 A and B, respectively. The observed spectra, derived temperatures, and estimated age combine to constrain the component spectral types to the range M6-M8. Evolutionary models predict masses of 113 +/- 8 M_Jup and 106 +/- 7 M_Jup from the estimated luminosities of the components. KPNO-Phoenix spectra allow us to estimate the systemic radial velocity of the binary. The Galactic kinematics of NLTT 33370AB are broadly consistent with other young stars in the Solar neighborhood. However, definitive membership in a young, kinematic group cannot be assigned at this time and further follow-up observations are necessary to fully constrain the system's kinematics. The proximity, age, and late-spectral type of this binary make it very novel and an ideal target for rapid, complete orbit determination. The system is one of only a few model calibration benchmarks at young ages and very low-masses.

motivations: There is a need to characterize and understand the properties of very low-mass binary systems, particularly at young ages.
The study of such systems can provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of low-mass stars and brown dwarfs.
objectives: Confirm the binary nature of the nearby, very low-mass system NLTT 33370 using adaptive optics imaging.
Characterize the system's properties, including its age, spectral types, temperatures, and masses, through photometry and spectroscopy.
Determine the systemic radial velocity and Galactic kinematics of the binary.
methods: Use adaptive optics imaging (VLT-NaCo and LBTI-LMIRCam) to resolve the binary and measure orbital motion.
Obtain near-infrared photometry and integrated light optical and near-infrared spectroscopy (VLT-SINFONI and KPNO-Phoenix) to characterize the system's properties.
Analyze the spectra and photometry to estimate the system's age, spectral types, temperatures, and masses.
results: Confirmation of the binary nature of NLTT 33370 and measurement of its orbital motion.
Estimation of the system's age (~30-200 Myr), spectral types (M6-M8), temperatures (3200-3100 K), and masses (113-106 M_Jup).
Determination of the systemic radial velocity and Galactic kinematics of the binary.

motivations: The binary nature of the very low-mass system NLTT 33370 is not fully understood and requires further investigation.
There is a need to characterize the system using near-infrared photometry and integrated light optical and near-infrared spectroscopy.
The system's age, proximity, and late-spectral type make it a novel and ideal target for complete orbit determination.
objectives: Confirm the binary nature of NLTT 33370 using adaptive optics imaging.
Characterize the system using resolved near-infrared photometry and integrated light optical and near-infrared spectroscopy.
Estimate the system's age, effective temperatures, and spectral types.
methods: Use VLT-NaCo and LBTI-LMIRCam images to observe orbital motion.
Apply optical spectra to reveal weak, gravity sensitive alkali lines and strong lithium absorption.
Use VLT-SINFONI near-IR spectra to show weak, gravity sensitive features and spectral morphology.
results: Confirmed the binary nature of NLTT 33370 and observed significant orbital motion.
Estimated a system age of ~30-200 Myr and effective temperatures of 3200 +/- 500 K and 3100 +/- 500 K for NLTT 33370 A and B, respectively.
Constrained the component spectral types to the range M6-M8 and predicted masses of 113 +/- 8 M_Jup and 106 +/- 7 M_Jup from the estimated luminosities of the components.
openai_json.research_subject: Characterization of the binary system NLTT 33370

motivations: Very low-mass binary systems at young ages are rare and provide crucial benchmarks for calibrating evolutionary models.
The binary nature of NLTT 33370 needed confirmation and comprehensive characterization to understand its properties and potential as a model calibration system.
objectives: Confirm the binary nature of NLTT 33370 and characterize its physical properties including age, temperature, and spectral types.
Determine the masses and kinematics of the system components to establish it as a benchmark for evolutionary model calibration.
methods: Used adaptive optics imaging with VLT-NaCo and LBTI-LMIRCam to detect orbital motion and resolve the binary components.
Performed optical and near-infrared spectroscopy to analyze gravity-sensitive features, lithium absorption, and spectral morphology.
Applied evolutionary models to derive component masses from luminosity estimates and analyzed Galactic kinematics.
results: Confirmed NLTT 33370 as a binary system with an estimated age of 30-200 Myr and component temperatures of approximately 3200K and 3100K.
Determined component masses of 113±8 and 106±7 Jupiter masses with spectral types in the M6-M8 range.
Established the system as one of few model calibration benchmarks for young, very low-mass binaries.
